definition: Short term negotiable debt securities issued by finance companies to fund consumer loans such as automobiles and appliances.
Amounts owed by a company for goods or services purchased and payable within one year, recorded as a current liability.
Amounts owed to a company for goods or services sold, expected to be collected within one year and recorded as a current asset.
Interest that has accumulated on a bond or debenture since the last interest payment date.
A company in which another corporation owns less than 50 percent of the voting shares or is under common control.
An investment dealer acting on behalf of a buyer or seller without taking ownership of the securities.
The systematic write off of the cost of an intangible asset over its useful life.
A formal report issued annually by a company containing audited financial statements and a review of operations.
The simultaneous purchase and sale of a security in different markets to profit from price differences.
Interest or dividends that were not paid when due and remain outstanding.
The lowest price at which a seller is willing to sell a security.
Resources owned or controlled by a company that are expected to provide future economic benefit.
A company owned jointly by two or more other companies.
An option whose exercise price is equal or nearly equal to the market price of the underlying security.
An independent examination of financial records to verify accuracy and compliance with accounting standards.
The maximum number of shares a company is legally permitted to issue.
Statistical measures used to track the performance of markets or economic activity.
The practice of buying additional units of a security at lower prices to reduce average cost.
A financial statement showing a company’s assets, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity at a specific date.
A disproportionately large payment due at the final maturity of a serial bond issue.
Canada’s central bank responsible for monetary policy, currency issuance, and financial system stability.
The minimum interest rate at which the Bank of Canada lends to major financial institutions.
A short term debt instrument guaranteed by a bank, reducing credit risk and yield.
A syndicate of investment dealers underwriting a new securities issue.
A legal status in which an individual or company cannot meet debt obligations.
One hundredth of a percentage point, commonly used to express yield differences.
A market environment characterized by declining prices.
A security whose ownership belongs to whoever physically holds the certificate.
The individual or entity that ultimately owns a security and receives its benefits.
An underwriting arrangement where the dealer does not guarantee sale of the entire issue.
The highest price a buyer is willing to pay for a security.
Shares of large, established companies with stable earnings and dividend histories.
The standard trading unit for a security on a stock exchange.
Debt securities where the issuer promises to pay interest and repay principal at maturity.
The net asset value of a company divided by its outstanding common shares.
A market environment characterized by rising prices.
Any day on which most businesses and financial institutions are open.
An option contract granting the right to buy a security at a specified price within a set time.
A security that can be redeemed by the issuer before maturity.
Financial resources or physical assets used to generate economic value.
Profit or loss resulting from the sale of a capital asset.
Net income adjusted for non cash expenses to reflect actual cash generation.
A national institution responsible for regulating money supply and monetary policy.
Short term unsecured debt issued by corporations.
Equity securities representing ownership with voting rights.
Interest calculated on both principal and previously earned interest.
Financial statements combining a parent company and its subsidiaries.
An inflation measure tracking changes in prices of a fixed basket of goods.
A security that can be converted into common shares.
The interest payment attached to a bond.
Assets expected to be converted into cash within one year.
Obligations due within one year.
A liquidity ratio measuring current assets divided by current liabilities.
Money borrowed that must be repaid with interest.
Failure to meet debt obligations as agreed.
The allocation of the cost of a tangible asset over its useful life.
Reduction in earnings per share caused by issuing additional shares.
Distributions of company profits to shareholders.
An investment strategy involving regular fixed investments over time.
Net income attributable to each common share outstanding.
Ownership interests in a corporation.
A stock trading without the right to the declared dividend.
The price at which an option can be exercised.
The date on which an option or right becomes invalid.
A dividend paid in addition to the regular dividend.
The amount printed on a bond or debenture certificate, representing the principal the issuer promises to repay at maturity, not the market value.
Failure to deliver a security on the settlement date or the agreed delivery date for a trade.
The price an asset would sell for between a willing buyer and a willing seller under normal conditions.
Client accounts where the dealer charges a fee based on account value rather than per trade commissions.
An order that must be executed immediately in full, otherwise any unfilled portion is cancelled.
The prospectus accepted for filing by securities regulators that contains complete information about a new issue and is provided to buyers.
Short term negotiable debt securities, similar to commercial paper, issued by finance companies.
Debt instruments or equity securities used to raise capital or invest, including loans, bonds, and shares.
An institution that accepts funds and invests or lends them on behalf of savers, such as banks, insurers, and mutual funds.
A firm bid commits to buy a specified amount at a stated price for a stated time unless released, a firm offer commits to sell under similar terms.
An inventory valuation method assuming the earliest purchased items are the first used or sold.
A dealer appointed by an issuer to advise on financing and manage underwriting or related financial matters.
Government policy that influences the economy through taxation and spending levels and allocation.
A company’s accounting year, which may differ from the calendar year.
A long term tangible asset held for use, such as land, buildings, and machinery.
Required ongoing expenses such as interest on debt that must be paid and reduce income.
Securities that provide predictable interest or dividend payments, such as bonds, debentures, and preferred shares.
A bond price quote that excludes accrued interest, often used when interest is in default.
Exchange floor personnel who execute buy and sell orders for their firm and clients.
Shares that pass eligible tax deductions and credits, often exploration related, from the corporation to the investor.
Rule based strategies that shift allocations based on market levels or triggers.
EPS calculated assuming all convertibles, options, and warrants are converted into common shares.
Security analysis based on business fundamentals such as sales, earnings, and dividends, rather than price patterns.
Long term debt obligations payable after one year, including bonds, debentures, and notes.
An agreement to buy or sell a commodity or financial asset at a future date under set terms.
A bond secured by a blanket mortgage on company property, typically subordinate to senior mortgages.
An intangible asset representing the premium paid over net asset value, often reflecting brand and reputation.
A Canadian dividend tax mechanism where eligible dividends are grossed up and a tax credit is applied, unlike interest income.
A stock of a company expected to grow, often reinvesting earnings instead of paying dividends, targeting capital gains.
An order valid until filled, cancelled, or until the close of business on a specified expiry date.
A good till cancelled order that remains active until executed or cancelled.
A deposit instrument paying a predetermined interest rate for a stated term, typically not redeemable or transferable before maturity.
A transaction intended to reduce exposure to price movements and limit potential losses.
The highest price paid for a security during a specified period.
A company that owns securities of other companies, often holding voting control.
An options strategy buying and selling the same type of option with the same strike price but different expiry months.
To pledge securities as collateral for a loan.
A conditional transaction for a security authorized but not yet issued, often trading before listing.
Buying and selling the same security over a short period to profit from short term price changes.
A call is in the money if strike is below market price, a put is in the money if strike is above market price.
A bond where interest is paid only if the issuer earns sufficient income, with unpaid interest sometimes accumulating.
A stock expected to pay an attractive dividend, typically from a mature company with slower growth.
A statistical measure tracking market or economic performance based on selected components.
A person with access to non public information, including directors, officers, certain professionals, and major shareholders.
A report of insiders’ transactions in a company’s shares submitted to regulators for monitoring.
A bond or debenture where portions of principal become due annually, also called a serial issue.
A new share issue paid in installments rather than one payment, also called partially paid shares.
Large clients such as banks, insurers, pensions, and corporations served by a dealer’s institutional desk.
A non physical asset such as goodwill, patents, trademarks, and copyrights.
A charge paid by a borrower to a lender for the use of funds.
Temporary certificates delivered at issuance that are later exchanged for definitive certificates.
Financial statements covering a period within a fiscal year, such as quarterly reports.
For options and rights, the amount by which the underlying market price exceeds the exercise price for calls, or is below for puts.
Goods held for sale or production inputs, and for dealers, securities held to facilitate trading and client positions.
Cost of goods sold divided by inventory, sometimes converted to days, indicating efficiency in selling inventory.
Ownership of assets to earn income, capital appreciation, or both.
A registered individual who provides investment advice and executes trades for clients.
A fee based specialist providing advice and research, typically for larger accounts.
A firm providing trading, underwriting, research, and advisory services via registered advisors.

term: Investment Industry Regulatory Organization of Canada (IIROC)
definition: Canada’s self regulatory organization overseeing investment dealers and trading activity on debt and equity marketplaces.
A market participant focused on minimizing risk relative to speculators, also a general term for anyone investing funds.
A company’s securities or the act of distributing them, issued shares are the portion of authorized shares sold.
An issuer’s offer to buy back its own securities, often because management views them as undervalued.
Execution and clearing of orders by one exchange member on behalf of another member.
A bond issue ranking behind senior debt because collateral or claims are pledged to higher priority issues.
Debt that ranks behind senior obligations in claims on assets and cash flows.
Indicators that tend to confirm economic trends after the economy has already shifted.
An inventory valuation method assuming the most recently purchased items are the first used or sold.
Indicators that tend to move ahead of the overall economy, such as employment and profits.
Rules in some provinces restricting trustees to approved lists of investments.
Use of fixed charges or borrowed funds that amplifies gains or losses, affecting earnings and returns.
A takeover financed largely with debt serviced by the acquired company’s cash flow and assets.
A company’s debts and obligations, classified as current if due within one year and long term otherwise.
A claim on pledged or mortgaged property to secure an obligation.
A contract providing regular payments for life in exchange for a lump sum, often using retirement funds.
An order to buy or sell at a specified price or better, setting a maximum buy price or minimum sell price.
Shareholders’ responsibility for company debts is limited to the amount invested in shares.
Converting assets to cash and distributing remaining proceeds after debts, typically paying preferred before common.
How easily a security can be traded without materially affecting price, also a measure of near term financial flexibility.
A stock traded on an exchange where the issuer meets listing standards and pays listing fees.
An exchange document describing a company when its shares are accepted for listing.
A mutual fund charge covering distribution costs, charged on purchase or redemption depending on structure.
A position with unrealized gain or loss that cannot be sold due to restrictions or lack of market.
A position indicating ownership of a security.
A bond or debenture with maturity longer than 10 years.
The lowest price paid for a security during a specified period.
The underlying long run price direction of a market despite short term moves.
A professionally managed portfolio with ongoing discretionary trading authority for a fee.
An account using borrowed funds from a dealer to buy securities, secured by collateral and subject to margin calls.
A designated trader expected to provide liquidity by maintaining bids and offers in certain securities.
An order to buy or sell immediately at the best available current price.
An underwriting clause allowing cancellation if markets change and the issue becomes unsaleable under specified conditions.
The most recent transaction price for a security.
Easily bought or sold in the market.
A significant change likely to affect a security’s market value or control, requiring disclosure to regulators.
The date a loan, bond, or debenture becomes due for repayment.
A bond or debenture maturing in more than three years but less than ten years.
An investment dealer that is a member of a stock exchange or IIROC.
The combination of companies into one continuing entity.
The portion of a subsidiary not owned by the parent, presented in consolidated statements to reflect outside ownership.
Central bank actions to influence credit conditions and money supply to achieve economic goals.
Market for short term obligations such as T bills, commercial paper, bankers’ acceptances, and similar instruments.
A loan agreement secured by real property, repaid typically through scheduled principal and interest payments.
Securities backed by pools of mortgages that pay interest and principal over time and trade based on interest rates.
Open end pooled investment vehicles that issue and redeem units, not generally exchange listed, with variable capitalization.
A U.S. self regulatory organization historically responsible for regulation of NASDAQ and OTC markets.
A U.S. electronic screen based market system for over the counter securities.
A debenture covenant limiting future secured borrowing unless the debentures receive similar security.
Transferable by delivery, and for registered certificates, properly endorsed and guaranteed.
Total assets minus liabilities, also called shareholders’ equity in many contexts.
The difference between a security’s closing price on consecutive trading days, adjusted for certain corporate actions.
Profit remaining after expenses and taxes, from which dividends may be paid.
Gross sales minus taxes, returns, allowances, and discounts or rebates.
Total assets minus total liabilities, also called equity.
A security offered for sale by an issuer for the first time, with proceeds used for financing or refinancing purposes.
Common shares with no stated face value, a common practice in Canada.
The stated interest rate not adjusted for inflation.
A preferred dividend feature where unpaid dividends do not accumulate.
An unsecured promise to pay, such as a promissory note.
A share quantity smaller than a board lot, or in some markets, an amount smaller than a standard trading unit.
Trades executed over the counter in unlisted securities, or special block trades not executed on an exchange.
Same as ask, the lowest price a seller will accept, contrasted with bid.
Shareholders listed on the issuer’s records as of a specified date and entitled to declared distributions or rights.

term: Open-End or Mutual Fund Investment Company
definition: An investment company that issues and redeems its own shares or units and is not exchange listed.
An order valid until executed or cancelled.
A trading method using verbal bids and offers on exchange floors, now largely replaced by electronic markets.
A contract giving the right, not obligation, to buy or sell an underlying security at a set price within a set time.
Securities that meet exchange requirements to serve as underlying instruments for listed options.
The buyer of a call or put option.
The price paid by the option buyer to the writer for the rights in the contract.
The seller of a call or put option who receives premium and assumes contractual obligations.
A call is out of the money if strike is above market price, a put is out of the money if strike is below market price.
A security trading at a level that appears inconsistent with comparable issues.
Shares that have been issued and are held by shareholders.
A dealer based market where securities trade outside exchanges via phone or electronic systems, common for bonds.
A short term negotiable debt security or promise to pay.
An unrealized gain on a security, realized only when the security is sold.
The stated face value of a bond, or an assigned value per share in corporate charter terms, often relevant for preferred shares.
In equal rank or proportion, often describing securities with equal claims.
A preferred share feature allowing participation in additional earnings beyond the fixed dividend.
Low priced speculative stocks, often defined as trading below a stated threshold such as $3 per share.
Warrants that upon exercise provide shares plus additional warrants issued later under stated terms.
Price increments where one point is $1 per share for stocks, and 1 percent of par for bonds and debentures.
A defensive plan allowing shareholders to buy additional shares at a discount if a takeover is triggered, raising takeover cost.
An acquisition accounting approach historically involving issuing shares for another company’s assets and combining at book values with adjustments.
The collection of investments held by an individual or institution.
Shares with priority over common in dividends and liquidation, typically paying fixed dividends and sometimes limited voting rights.
An amount above par or stated value, also the price paid for an option contract.
A valuation ratio equal to share price divided by earnings per share, used to compare equities.
The initial sale of a new security issue by the issuer.
The interest rate banks charge their most creditworthy borrowers.
The dealer acting for its own account, also the invested capital or face value of a bond depending on context.
A preferred share class ranking ahead of other preferred shares for dividends and liquidation proceeds.
Securities sold privately to a limited number of typically sophisticated buyers without a public prospectus.
Financial information presented as if a transaction occurred at an earlier date to illustrate expected impact.
In proportion, for example dividends paid based on shares owned.
Selling securities to realize gains and convert unrealized profits into cash.
Computerized trading strategies exploiting price relationships between portfolios and related index futures or options.
A legal disclosure document describing securities offered to the public and relevant issuer information.
Authorization allowing someone to vote a shareholder’s shares at a meeting.
A trustee standard requiring investments consistent with what a prudent person would buy for others’ benefit.
A fund used to retire outstanding preferred shares or debt by buying securities in the market under set limits.
In a split, delivery of new shares directly to registered holders without requiring surrender of old certificates.
Options granting the right to sell an underlying security at a specified price within a set time.
The current highest bid and lowest offer for a security.
A swift rise in market prices or the price of a specific security.
A temporary decline following an upward price move.
An investment vehicle that holds real estate related assets and distributes income, traded as a security.
Nominal interest rate minus inflation, often measured using CPI change.
The date determining which shareholders are entitled to dividends, rights, or other distributions.
A preliminary prospectus used to gauge interest while under regulatory review, not containing all final details.
Issuer repurchase of securities from holders under specified terms, time, and price.
Issuing new securities to repay existing obligations, often to reduce cost or extend maturity.
A registered trust providing employee pension benefits with tax deductible contributions.
A registered professional, now commonly called an investment advisor, who advises clients and executes trades.
A tax deferral vehicle funded from an RRSP that requires minimum annual withdrawals taxed as income.
A retirement savings plan with tax deductible contributions and tax deferred growth until withdrawal.
A security recorded in the owner’s name on issuer records, transferable through endorsed certificates and transfer agents.
Government approved plans such as RPPs, RRSPs, and RRIFs where growth is tax deferred subject to rules.
A trust company or agent responsible for issuing and registering security certificates.
Filing securities for distribution under securities laws, also the licensing of dealers and representatives with regulators.
A company with securities held by the public that must meet continuous disclosure requirements.
Agreements where a seller sells a security and commits to repurchase it later, commonly used in government securities markets.
In technical analysis, a price level that tends to cap advances because selling interest increases.
Shares with limited or no voting rights that otherwise participate in earnings and liquidation like common shares.
Cumulative profits kept in the business after expenses and dividends, used to fund operations and growth.
A feature allowing holders to redeem a security on a specified date under defined conditions, often before maturity.
The income and or capital gain earned on an investment.
Combining shares into fewer shares, increasing price per share and reducing shares outstanding.
A time limited privilege allowing existing shareholders to buy additional shares at a set price, often below market.
A purchaser’s right to cancel a new issue purchase within legal time limits if disclosure was materially incorrect or incomplete.
A purchaser’s right to withdraw from a new issue purchase within a short period after receiving the prospectus.
The probability or possibility of loss or adverse outcomes.
A certificate representing fractional share entitlements exchangeable for cash by a stated date.
Traditional term for membership on a stock exchange.
The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, a federal securities regulator.
A public resale of a large block of shares after the initial issuance, often priced relative to market.
Markets where existing securities trade after issuance, including exchanges and OTC markets.
Transferable investment instruments such as stocks, bonds, notes, futures, and options.
A provincial authority responsible for administering securities legislation.
A registered person or firm providing general securities advice, often through publications.
A provincial body overseeing securities laws and market conduct.
Transforming loans into tradable securities by pooling assets and selling claims on the pool, also broader disintermediation via markets.
Industry organizations that set and enforce market and member conduct rules under delegated authority.
Dealers assisting with distribution of a new issue without taking underwriting financial responsibility.
A bond issue with priority claims over junior issues on assets and earnings.
Debt ranking ahead of other obligations in claims on assets and cash flows.
A bond or debenture with principal maturing in scheduled amounts over multiple years.
The date payment and delivery must occur for a securities transaction, typically two business days in Canada.
An owner of preferred or common shares of a company.
Owners’ residual interest in a company, equal to assets minus liabilities.
A shareholder registered on issuer records and entitled to distributions and rights as of record dates.
Certificates representing ownership in a corporation and claims on earnings and assets.
Selling securities not owned with intent to buy back later at lower price, disclosed as a short sale at order time.
A bond or debenture maturing within three years.
Borrowings repayable within one year, shown in current liabilities, such as loans, notes payable, and near term maturities.
A fund used to retire debt or preferred shares gradually before maturity through scheduled purchases or payments.
A participant accepting calculated risk for potentially higher returns, often focused on short to medium term gains.
The difference between bid and ask, also the price difference targeted in certain options or commodity strategies.

term: Statement of Changes in Financial Position
definition: A statement explaining sources and uses of funds and changes in working capital over a period, linking successive balance sheets.
A disclosure document used in certain underwritings or secondary distributions when shares are exchange listed, replacing a prospectus in specific cases.
Combining existing shares into fewer shares, another term for reverse split.
A dividend paid in shares rather than cash.
An organized marketplace for trading stocks under defined rules and standards.
An indicator measuring value changes for a defined group of stocks.
Provincial programs providing tax credits or deductions for investing in prescribed vehicles in certain provinces.
Increasing shares outstanding by dividing existing shares into more shares without changing proportional ownership.
A short identifier used to represent a security on an exchange.

term: Stop Limit Sell and Stop Limit Buy Orders
definition: Orders that activate when a stop price is reached, becoming limit orders, with execution not guaranteed if price moves past the limit.
Holding securities through a dealer in nominee name rather than physical certificates, with payments credited to the client account.
The price at which an option can be exercised to buy or sell the underlying security.

term: Strip Bonds or Zero Coupon Bonds
definition: Bonds created by separating coupons from principal so components trade at discounts, also called zero coupon structures.
Debentures separated from attached instruments such as warrants that were originally issued together.
A non binding indication of buying or selling interest that does not commit the participant to transact.
A company controlled by another, typically through majority ownership.
Shareholders’ equity components from sources other than retained earnings, and the broader concept of accumulated earnings retained.
An additional tax applied on top of regular income tax, often temporary.
A feature added to a new issue to increase attractiveness, such as warrants or convertibility.
Selling one security and buying another, often to change exposure or improve expected return.
A group of dealers underwriting and distributing a new issue or large block of securities.
An offer to buy voting securities that would bring ownership above a threshold requiring takeover bid rules.
An income range to which a specific marginal tax rate applies.
A reduction in taxes payable that generally applies equally per dollar of credit regardless of marginal rate.
An investment structure designed to provide tax savings such as deductions, credits, or deferral.
A short term government treasury bill sold at a discount and maturing at par.
Analysis using price and volume patterns to infer investor behavior and potential future price action.
A bank deposit for a stated term and rate, often with penalties or lower rates for early withdrawal.
A market with few bids or offers causing larger price moves between trades due to low liquidity.
An order that specifies the time window during which it can be executed.
The portion of an option or right’s price above intrinsic value, reflecting time and volatility.
An issuer’s obligation to promptly release material information to the public.
A dealer employee executing orders, also a client who trades frequently seeking short term profits.
A temporary suspension of trading to allow dissemination of material information.
Standard par value units for OTC trading, varying by instrument type such as treasury bills or bonds.
The date on which a purchase or sale occurs.
An appointed entity maintaining shareholder records and often handling certificate transfers and dividend distributions.
Short term government debt sold at a discount and maturing at par, with gain treated as interest income.
Authorized but unissued shares, or issued shares repurchased and held by the issuer.
A party holding assets or overseeing bondholder protections under trust deed covenants, also a fiduciary holding assets for others.
The securities that are bought or sold when an option is exercised.
The purchase of a new issue by dealers for resale, governed by underwriting agreements.
Two or more securities offered together at a single combined price.
A security not listed on an exchange and typically traded OTC.
Financing provided to fund new and higher risk business ventures.
The degree of price variation of a security over time.
The number of shares or contracts traded over a period.
The right to vote on corporate matters, often one vote per common share, with proxy voting possible.
An arrangement where shareholders transfer voting rights to a trustee for a defined period to centralize control.
A certificate giving the right to buy securities at a specified price within a specified time.
Current assets minus current liabilities, indicating short term liquidity.
Current assets divided by current liabilities, also called the current ratio.
Effective control of a company that may be achieved with less than 50 percent ownership in practice.
A discretionary managed account charging a single asset based fee instead of per trade commissions and charges.
Return expressed as a percentage, for stocks dividend yield, for bonds a rate based on interest and price relationships.
A graph showing yields for similar quality bonds across different maturities.
The total annualized return expected if a fixed income security is held to maturity.
Bonds that pay no periodic interest and trade at discounts to par, with return realized at maturity, also called strip bonds.
